org.zuinnote.hadoop.bitcoin.format.common

Class BitcoinBlockReader

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.zuinnote.hadoop.bitcoin.format.common.BitcoinBlockReader

  • public class BitcoinBlockReader
extends java.lang.Object
    This class reads Bitcoin blocks (in raw network format) from an input stream and returns Java objects of the class BitcoinBlock. It reuses code from the LineRecordReader due to its robustness and well-tested functionality.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      BitcoinBlockReader(java.io.InputStream in, int maxSizeBitcoinBlock, int bufferSize, byte[][] specificMagicByteArray, boolean useDirectBuffer)
      Create a BitcoinBlock reader that reads from the given stream and uses the given parameters for configuration.

      Create a BitcoinBlock reader that reads from the given stream and uses the given parameters for configuration.

      BitcoinBlock readBlock()
      Read a block into a Java object of the class Bitcoin Block.
      java.nio.ByteBuffer readRawBlock() 
      void seekBlockStart()
      Seek for a valid block start according to the following algorithm: (1) find the magic of the block (2) Check that the block can be fully read and that block size is smaller than maximum block size This functionality is particularly useful for file processing in Big Data systems, such as Hadoop and Co where we work indepently on different filesplits and cannot expect that the Bitcoin block starts directly at the beginning of the stream;

    • Constructor Detail

      • BitcoinBlockReader

        public BitcoinBlockReader(java.io.InputStream in,
                          int maxSizeBitcoinBlock,
                          int bufferSize,
                          byte[][] specificMagicByteArray,
                          boolean useDirectBuffer)
        Create a BitcoinBlock reader that reads from the given stream and uses the given parameters for configuration. Note it assumed that the validity of this configuration is checked by BitcoinBlockRecordReader
        Parameters:
        in - Input stream to read from
        maxSizeBitcoinBlock - Maximum size of a Bitcoinblock.
        bufferSize - size of the memory buffer for the givenInputStream
        specificMagicByteArray - filters by specific block magic numbers if not null.
        useDirectBuffer - experimental feature to use a DirectByteBuffer instead of a HeapByteBuffer

      • BitcoinBlockReader

        public BitcoinBlockReader(java.io.InputStream in,
                          int maxSizeBitcoinBlock,
                          int bufferSize,
                          byte[][] specificMagicByteArray,
                          boolean useDirectBuffer,
                          boolean readAuxPow)
        Create a BitcoinBlock reader that reads from the given stream and uses the given parameters for configuration. Note it assumed that the validity of this configuration is checked by BitcoinBlockRecordReader
        Parameters:
        in - Input stream to read from
        maxSizeBitcoinBlock - Maximum size of a Bitcoinblock.
        bufferSize - size of the memory buffer for the givenInputStream
        specificMagicByteArray - filters by specific block magic numbers if not null.
        useDirectBuffer - experimental feature to use a DirectByteBuffer instead of a HeapByteBuffer
        readAuxPow - true if auxPow information should be parsed, false if not

    • Method Detail

      • seekBlockStart

        public void seekBlockStart()
                    throws BitcoinBlockReadException
        Seek for a valid block start according to the following algorithm: (1) find the magic of the block (2) Check that the block can be fully read and that block size is smaller than maximum block size This functionality is particularly useful for file processing in Big Data systems, such as Hadoop and Co where we work indepently on different filesplits and cannot expect that the Bitcoin block starts directly at the beginning of the stream;
        Throws:
        BitcoinBlockReadException - in case of format errors of the Bitcoin Blockchain data

      • readBlock

        public BitcoinBlock readBlock()
                       throws BitcoinBlockReadException
        Read a block into a Java object of the class Bitcoin Block. This makes analysis very easy, but might be slower for some type of analytics where you are only interested in small parts of the block. In this case it is recommended to use readRawBlock()
        Returns:
        BitcoinBlock
        Throws:
        BitcoinBlockReadException - in case of errors of reading the Bitcoin Blockchain data

      • parseAuxPow

        public BitcoinAuxPOW parseAuxPow(java.nio.ByteBuffer rawByteBuffer)
        Parses AuxPOW information (cf. https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Merged_mining_specification)
        Parameters:
        rawByteBuffer -
        Returns:

        public BitcoinAuxPOWBranch parseAuxPOWBranch(java.nio.ByteBuffer rawByteBuffer)
        Parse an AUXPowBranch
        Parameters:
        rawByteBuffer - ByteBuffer from which the AuxPOWBranch should be parsed
        Returns:
        AuxPOWBranch

      • parseTransactions

        public java.util.List<BitcoinTransaction> parseTransactions(java.nio.ByteBuffer rawByteBuffer,
                                                            long noOfTransactions)
        Parses the Bitcoin transactions in a byte buffer.
        Parameters:
        rawByteBuffer - ByteBuffer from which the transactions have to be parsed
        noOfTransactions - Number of expected transactions
        Returns:
        Array of transactions

      • getKeyFromRawBlock

        public byte[] getKeyFromRawBlock(java.nio.ByteBuffer rawByteBuffer)
        This function is used to read from a raw Bitcoin block some identifier. Note: Does not change ByteBuffer position
        Parameters:
        rawByteBuffer - ByteBuffer as read by readRawBlock
        Returns:
        byte array containing hashMerkleRoot and prevHashBlock

      • close

        public void close()
           throws java.io.IOException
        Closes the reader
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - in case of errors reading from the InputStream
